page.title: 19WILD LIFE OF THE UPLAND
page.content: THE LAND RISES 160 FT. UP TO THE MOORS WHERE THE HABITAT FOR WILD LIFE CHANGES. DECIDUOUS AND CONIFER WOODS PROVIDE HABITAT FOR THE BIRDS, BLUE, GREAT, AND LONG-TAILED TITS FEED ON THE CONIFER SEEDS. TREE CREEPERS, SPOTTED FLY-CATCHERS, TOGETHER WITH WHEAT EAR WHINCHAT, WOODCOCK AND THE SHORT-EARED OWL USE THE SHELTER OF THE WOODED LAND. ON THE OPEN MOOR ARE THE GROUSE, SNIPE, RING OUSEL, CURLEW AND THE GOLDEN AND GREEN PLOVERS. THE PREDITORS; SPARROWHAWK, KESTREL AND MERLIN ARE MAINLY ON THE HIGHER GROUND. THE GRASSY HEATHLAND ATTRACTS THE GRASS AND HEATH-FEEDING MOTHS, THE EMPEROR, NORTHERN EGGAR, FOX, DRINKER, RUBY TIGER AND WOOD TIGER ARE ALL TO BE FOUND ON THESE MOORS. ADDERS, SLOW WORMS AND THE PALMATE NEWT ALSO LIVE UP HERE.
